title: Looking for a Didot/Bodoni Sans
content:
I'm trying to locate a commercially available typeface approximating the look of a Bodoni or Didot Sans. I'm aware of Peter Bilak's unpublished Didot Sans, but have yet to find anything that captures the same spirit. I've located numerous, Deco-styled faces that have the thick/thin qualities of a Didot, but the contrast is typically too exaggerated and the proportions too condensed.   
   
Creating a new face isn't an option as the budget on the job does not allow for the time needed to do so...   
   
Does anyone know of any typefaces out there that preserve the classic proportions of a Didot, minus it's serifs? Any assisitance would be greatly appreciated.   
   
Thanks.
author: studioblue

comments.content:
Stephen: it seems that contrast is something that he wants?   
   
Garrett, sorry, I have no idea. But there

If I remember rightly, I have read that the original 19th century 'Grotesques' are in fact based on 'modern' proportions such as Didot and Bodoni. The progression was first to thick unbracketed serifs of 'Egyptians', and then these had the serifs cut off & voila.

Britannic has always struck me as being one of the most successful high-contrast sans serif faces.   
However, it has the full curves of a grotesque, not the more geometric, neoclassical shapes of Bodoni-era "moderns".   
   
The over-extension and turning back of the curved terminals in "c", for instance, provide the opportunity for a purposeful end to the stroke, not just snipping it off, which would be the minimal, pure-didone logic.   
   
So, it would make a good pairing not with the original moderns, but with more contemporary (ie c.1900) moderns such as, ahem, Monotype Modern 2, or De Vinne.   
   
For a 3some, add Grot. #9.   
   
If in doubt for matching faces, make them from the same era.

This is completely unhelpful to you, but here's a typeface   
that preserves the proportions of Bodoni, minus the stroke   
modulation and with slab serifs: [Bodoni Egyptian](http://web.archive.org/web/20110818115015/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/shinn/bodoni-egyptian/). You   
could chop off the serifs, but I'm not sure how good   
the results would be.
